This property verifies that the mode[5:0] signal correctly captures the previous value of din[5:0] under specific control conditions.

The property triggers on every positive edge of the clk when all the following conditions are simultaneously true: CS equals 1, WR equals 1, cmd equals 1, and either din[5] equals 1 or din[4] equals 1.

When this trigger condition occurs, the property requires that on the very next clock cycle (one clock cycle later), the value of mode[5:0] must exactly match the value that din[5:0] had at the time of the trigger condition. The $past function is used to reference this previous value of din[5:0].

If this expected behavior is not met, the assertion will fail with an error message indicating that mode[5:0] does not match the previous value of din[5:0].

# SVA Generation Chain-of-Thought

**Property:** p_mode_assignment_logic
**Type:** Assertion

## Step 1: Interface & Clock Domain Analysis

* **Signals:**
    * Design Signals: `CS`, `WR`, `cmd`, `din`, `mode`

* **Clocks & Resets:**
    * Primary Clock: `clk` (posedge)

* **Cross-Domain Check:** 
    * Single clock domain - no CDC concerns

## Step 2: Semantic Mapping (Primitives & Built-ins)

* **Boolean Conditions:**
    * Trigger condition: `(CS == 1 && WR == 1 && cmd == 1 && (din[5] == 1 || din[4] == 1))`
    * Response condition: `##1 mode[5:0] == $past(din[5:0])`

* **Edge/Change Detection & Built-in Functions:**
    * `$past(din[5:0])`: Reference to signal value from previous cycles

* **Past Values:**
    * Reference to previous value of `din[5:0]`

## Step 3: Sequence Construction (Bottom-Up)

* **Sequence A (Trigger/Antecedent):**
    * Description: The triggering condition that initiates property evaluation
    * Logic: `(CS == 1 && WR == 1 && cmd == 1 && (din[5] == 1 || din[4] == 1))`

* **Sequence B (Response/Consequent):**
    * Description: The expected behavior when trigger occurs
    * Logic: `##1 mode[5:0] == $past(din[5:0])`
    * Timing: 1 cycle(s)

* **Temporal Operators Used:**
    * `##`: Cycle delay operator

## Step 4: Property Assembly

* **Implication Type:**
    * Overlapping (`|->`) - consequent evaluation starts in the same cycle as antecedent match

* **Disable Condition:**
    * None specified - property always active

* **Assertion Structure:**
    * `@(posedge clk) (CS == 1 && WR == 1 && cmd == 1 && (din[5] == 1 || din[4] == 1)) |-> ##1 mode[5:0] == $past(din[5:0])`

## Step 5: Final SVA Code

```systemverilog
property p_mode_assignment_logic;
    @(posedge clk)
        (CS == 1 && WR == 1 && cmd == 1 && (din[5] == 1 || din[4] == 1)) |-> ##1 mode[5:0] == $past(din[5:0]);
endproperty
assert_p_mode_assignment_logic: assert property (p_mode_assignment_logic) else $error("Assertion failed: mode[5:0] does not match the previous value of din[5:0] when CS, WR, and cmd are all 1 and either din[5] or din[4] is 1");
```

**Summary:**
Property `p_mode_assignment_logic` uses overlapping implication synchronized to `clk` using built-in functions: $past.
